social_posts.post_text: An idea for Lahaina’s future. Mahalo @spectrumnewshi August 26th

Petition is in my bio. Please, give us a moment to breathe. Our community is filled with souls bearing burdens so immense, they've altered the essence of who we are. Before you push us back into 'business as usual,' understand that we need time to find even a sliver of peace, a sanctuary to mend our broken hearts. Do not rob us of these sacred moments; they are the bandages for our collective wounds. And when it comes to reopening our doors to the world, let that choice be ours to make. Our island isn't just a tourist destination, it's the home of our souls. Rushing us jeopardizes the fragile peace we're painstakingly piecing together. We'll know when we're ready; until then, let us heal in our own time, in our own way.

Every whisper of our ‘āina, every heartbeat of our people, resonates in Lāhainā’s very soul. We will not, cannot, stand still when they cry out. Lāhainā’s spirit will always rise, fierce and unwavering, to answer their call. Reinstate Kaleo!!!
Paele Kiakona ✊🏾 #lahainastrong
What an intense display of people power. This is community organizing. When disaster tears through a community, you find a way to bind it back together. #LahainaStrong (from PBS News Hour)

“It takes a village...” 

You’ll probably hear that a lot throughout your lifetime. It’s a proverb that describes the effort it takes to teach and raise a child or the effort it takes to tackle something monumental that requires a lot of hearts, hands, and commitment.

Though what you might not hear as often is that it takes ‘āina, too.

‘Āina is what happens when people, place, and practice come together to create abundance, an abundance anchored in aloha that cradles, enables, and sustains life. Especially in times like these.

The teachers and families who are a part of the Hawaiian language immersion school system have always grounded themselves this way, teaching and learning basic subjects like math, science, and a slew of other “standards” in ways that create and foster intergenerational relationships and connections that enable ‘āina to thrive. And they’ve historically done it with less funding and less facility support than some of their English-only counterparts. 

Today, in spite of ongoing challenges and the suffocating losses from the recent fires, they continue to breathe life and bring ea to the spaces they engage; They are leaning even more into the community, leaning into their village, and like they have always done, they are embracing ‘āina. And the ‘āina embraces them back, healing them, teaching them, holding them in aloha.

As kumu Kanoe Steward, her kane Kalama’ehu Takahashi, nā kumu kaiapuni, and the ‘ohana of Maui steadfastly show us: though the houses and physical structures of their towns may have burned down in the tragic fire, they still have a home they are deeply connected to. And they have the foundations and structures in place to restore and rebuild things on Maui in the best ways possible. 

To support the teachers and families of kula kaiapuni who have been impacted by the fires: tinyurl.com/ohanakaiapuni [link in bio]

To support the kula kaiapuni teachers affected by the fires:

Kanoe Steward/Takahashi (Venmo): Kanoelani-Steward

Liko Rogers (GoFundMe): bradley-rogers-29

Teva Medeiros (Venmo): embahh

#lahainastrong #lahaina #maui #mauistrong
Please join me in sending a email to Dawn.chang@hawaii.gov and kindly request her to schedule the October 3 meeting in person in West Maui for more than 2 hours to allow more people to testify.

Mahalo nui loa Representative Elle Cochran for taking a stand and showing support for the people of Lahaina! 

We know where you stand. People over Profit. 
#Lahainastrong

This past week, hundreds of West Maui residents met with county leaders to talk about rebuilding Lahaina. Many agree they don’t want the town to return to what it once was before the fire. From @kitv4:

“A sea of red-clad Lahaina residents filled the ballroom at the Westin Maui Resort & Spa. Community members had the chance to meet with Maui County Council members – and offer input for developing a comprehensive recovery and resiliency plan addressing the wildfire.

Some called for better roadways besides the one-way-in-one-way-out design that complicated the evacuation in this past tragedy. Others demanded a moratorium on outside investors trying to buy land from people who lost their homes if they decide to sell – and to offer locals priority.

But many echoed the rebuilding process is the right time to reshape Lahaina town – one less reliant on tourists, with less development and more native agriculture and greenery.

‘For us, I think to understand as a community and for us as a people in all of Hawaii and all across the world is that our oiwi, our native peoples, our ways and our history, and our genealogies, they come first,’ said Holden Kalamaʻehu Takahashi.

‘The Lahaina that we were used to, you didn’t really see a lot of local people down there. We didn’t really go down there unless we were maybe going to the movies or, you know, maybe a special restaurant. But other than that it wasn’t really a place for us,’ said Kanoelani Steward.

During the meeting, county officials say there will be other opportunities for community members to share their thoughts on the rebuilding process.”

Watch the video story [link in bio]

#lahainastrong #lahaina #mauistrong #maui

@govjoshgreen they are already here and are already causing problems within an already hurt and struggling community. By ignoring the pleas of the community and opening the floodgates on the two month anniversary of the destruction of our beloved Lahaina you have shown where your intentions lie and who your loyalty lies with.  All of these altercations are on your hands.
Please share so we can bring clarity to our visitors across the world. The disconnect between our government and our community

People have been wondering why, in the aftermath of a deadly fire, we are fighting to protect water rights and to change the way tourism operates. 

The reason is because everything is connected. This is the system our great great grandparents were sucked into and the same one that we are still stuck in today. 

Take a closer look at the grim realities of Hawaii’s history, where the destructive forces of plantations and the tourism industry have left lasting scars on the islands and their people. It’s time to confront the damage caused and demand a change in the way tourism operates in Hawaii. 

A Legacy of Exploitation: The plantation industry’s insatiable hunger for profits drove the ruthless exploitation of Hawaiian lands and labor force. Ahupuaʻa self-sustainability was shattered, leaving communities vulnerable and dependent on unsustainable practices.

Ecological Devastation: Plantations brought about widespread environmental degradation, as vast stretches of land were cleared for mono-crop agriculture, chemical-intensive farming practices took hold, and water resources were drained for irrigation. The delicate ecosystems that once thrived were disrupted, endangering native flora and fauna.

Hidden Realities: Behind the glossy postcard images lie the hidden stories of displaced communities, cultural erasure, and the erosion of traditional knowledge. The true cost of tourism is often obscured, as the industry capitalizes on Hawaiian culture while neglecting the voices and well-being of the local inhabitants.

A Broken Paradise: The tourism industry, born from the ruins of the plantation era, perpetuates a cycle of exploitation. Local communities are pushed aside while multinational corporations profit from the commodification of Hawaiian culture, natural resources, and labor.

Demanding Change: It’s time to break free from the destructive patterns of the past and demand a transformation in the tourism industry. We must prioritize the well-being of the land, its people, and their cultural heritage. Sustainable practices, community empowerment, and fair representation are the keys to a more equitable and responsible future for Hawaiʻi.

EPIC! Turn up your sound to sing and dance to Lahaina youth alongside members of Lahaina Grown, bringing you todayʻs #Mele4Maui - an anthem of, by, and for Lahaina.

@mana_maoli was honored to team up with Lahaina Grown, @thisisirielove, and some of Mauiʻs top musicians to bring @mauihighsabers its 1st ever schoolwide assembly for any of its current students (due to the pandemic).

After Lahaina youth shared manaʻo of their experiences in a small group setting over lunch with Irie Love and @he_iwi (lead vocalist of Lahaina Grown), they started off the assembly singing Lahainalunaʻs alma mater, and some shared powerful testimony of their experiences to the whole school, with a chance for the artists to respond, while showered with aloha from their peers. 

Others joined the artists onstage to sing, and hundreds of Maui high students joined Lahaina youth in storming the dance floor, like you see here for “Lahaina Grown” composed by Albert Napahi Dizon III, a song whose lyrics are no less timely and relevant today, then when it 1st became a hit song 18 years ago!

We continue to send our aloha and healing to our West Maui ʻohana affected by the fires. See link in bio to donate, and for other ways to support.

Mahalo NUI to the artists - @he_iwi, @thisisirielove, @themaadking808 @nahuasdaddy39 @kana_mon, Uncle Chris Dizon, and Jacob De La Nux. 

Mahalo NUI nō hoʻi to Maui High schoolʻs admin, teachers and students, all Lahainaluna youth at Maui high, as well as our crew. A special mahalo to Mana Maoli Events Manager @chee_ihi and Maui Highʻs SAC Glenda Joyo who along with their teams worked tirelessly to make this epic day happen. We appreciate you!

Last but not least, props to the @lahainalunahighschool youth featured onstage for this mele:
Kamryn Bosque @k.anoelani
Aleyah Falealii Jenkins @xo.leiaa
Jennifer Rincon-Melchor @http.jen.ny
Joshua Nerona: @publicjsh
Henes Giann Rasos: @gie_tzy
Randel Buemio: @luvrandel
Zean Leighton Lagpacan: @2jzean
Gian Andres: @who.is_gian
Rhalp Rivera: @rhalp.rivera
Jenson Rante: @jensonrante
Mark Villamar: @markcollinvillamar

We hosted a remarkable community art party in Lahaina to support the fire victims and embrace the power of art for healing. With some donated goods, amazing food and a shared spirit, we continue to come together as we rebuild and restore our beloved hometown.

Im a final attempt to have him hear us out, we invited @govjoshgreen to come listen to the community he makes decisions for.  Despite Governor Josh Green’s absence, we are grateful to Senator Angus Mckelvey, Mayor Richard Bissen, and representatives from the ILWU for joining us in this community gathering and talking with our community members. 

We even saved a seat for the governor throughout the entire event, hoping he would join us and witness the strength and resilience of our community. While disappointed by his absence, we celebrated an incredible day filled with music, delicious food, awesome jams by Lahaina Grown, and the commUNITY that binds us together. 🎶🌮

Thank you to everyone who participated and contributed to making this event a success. Huge mahalo to chef Lisa Villiarimo, chef Sheldon Simeon, Lily from the Noodle bar and Waikomo shave ice!!! Together, we continue to support one another, rebuild what was lost, and create a brighter future for Lahaina. 🎨✨💪 #CommunityStrong #HealingThroughArt #LahainaStrong #UnityInAdversity #Touriststoosoon

After intense pressure from the community, Kaleo Manuel has been reinstated. Will there be a more detailed explanation and a public apology too?

From the State’s press release: Dawn Chang, Chairperson of the Commission on Water Resource Management (CWRM), announced today that Kaleo Manuel, 1st Deputy to the Chairperson of CWRM, will return to his post effective immediately.

On August 15, 2023, the Attorney General had requested that Manuel be deployed to another DLNR Division until her investigation of certain personnel events related to the August 8, 2023, Maui wildfires was completed. 

“I was informed today, that the Attorney General has completed her review of this isolated issue. I would like to thank Dean Uyeno for stepping in as the Acting Deputy Director of CWRM and appreciate his steady leadership of CWRM during this unprecedented time,” Chang said. 

#lahainastrong #lahaina #maui #mauistrong

With all the media coverage around Kaleo’s reinstatement, the Governor and his administration are not saying much other than what was shared in a brief statement. The Civil Beat, the original news outlet that eagerly pushed an incomplete narrative that took on a life of its own amongst radical and influential extremist groups, has not said much about the reinstatement either, other than a quick-and-you’ll-miss-it mention that got buried in the news cycle. 

Kaleo has maintained his dignity by taking the high road throughout the entire ordeal in spite of the attacks on his character and the vicious threats to him and his ‘ohana.

Residents, advocates, water protectors, and everyday people who need water are glad he is back. And many are asking for a public explanation and apology from those responsible for the wrongs leveled upon Kaleo, kalo farmers, and Hawaiian culture. An explanation and apology would go a long way to ensure the hard work Hawai’i has ahead can move forward in a pono way.

Kaleo’s partner, @kastar08 had this to share with everyone:

No Kaleo Ka Paio Mau 🧡

WE are so grateful and would like to extend our mahalo to everyone for all the kāko’o, kōkua, and aloha within the last several weeks.

WE also want to mahalo our immediate ‘ohana, for always standing behind + beside us to kua the many kuleana that have come our way. WE are WE because of ALL of you.

But…WE are not pau 😉 As triumphant as this reinstatement is, there is still much overdue pono to be done. 

So eia ku’u kāhea- 
Please join us in DEMANDING a formal public apology from Dawn Chang & Josh Green. WE will not allow their hana ‘ino, hana hewa, kuhi hewa, mihi ‘ole, and ho’oponopono ‘ole to slide.

Please email Dawn & Josh demanding that a formal public apology to our entire ‘ohana (Manuel, Isoshima, Lindsey, Asing) and kaiāulu be made by October 24th. Failure to apologize by October 24th will result in further action of kū’ē, ‘onipa’a, and paiō from the collective lāhui.

Please email your letters to:

dawn.chang@hawaii.gov
kanani.kealalio@hawaii.gov
governor.green@hawaii.gov
brooke.wilson@hawaii.gov

#NoKaleoKeKūpaʻa
#NoKaleoKaPaiōMau
#lahainastrong
#mauistrong

📸: @kastar08

What would have saved the beloved town of Lahaina and all the lives that were lost? How can Maui County officials prevent this from ever happening again?

[Retired Maui Fire Battalion Chief] Lonokailua-Hewett says you have to know the past to understand the present and to change the future. “The Kaua’ula winds come to my mind,” he said.

Literature tells us the Kaua’ula Wind is famous for its power — clocked at 120 miles an hour — coming from ʻĪao Valley, down Kaua’ula Valley and known to tear down everything in its path.

So, what has prevented deadly and devastating firestorms from happening in the past?

“Lahainaluna, the alma mater, it talks about Malu ’Ulu o Lele, which means that this is a place where there were ’ulu groves,” Lonokailua-Hewett said.

“That’s protection for sure, which means that there also was water. The alma mater also says ua kilikilihune hoʻopulu i ke oho o ka palai, which means the sprinkling rain that used to dampen the fronds of the palai. Those are examples of water being present here.”

For over a century, water was diverted to irrigate the plantations in Lahaina. The fight over water in West Maui continues today. Lonokailua-Hewett says if nothing is done, history will repeat itself.

“The winds will come back. This town will always be hot,” he said.

“There’s always going to be potential for fire. So, unless we do something about the surrounding areas around our community the devastation will return.”

The headline and excerpt was taken from a @hawaiinewsnow story by @chelseadavishnn originally posted on October 11, 2023. For the full story visit the HNN website [link in bio].

#lahainastrong #lahaina #maui #mauistrong

Rise, Rebuild, Remember: The Heartbeat of Lahaina Calls Us 🌺🔨

We’ve listened to the earnest words of Lawrence Cabanilla, a true son of Lahaina, whose love for his hometown outshines even the relentless Lahaina sun. Despite all odds, he can still find a reason to smile when he thinks of Lahaina. But he may never witness the restoration of his cherished home. This is more than a call to arms - it’s a call to hearts.

To our esteemed community leaders, let us set aside our individual agendas and embrace the collective vision of Lahaina’s future. Let us lead by example, showing our community that self-determination isn’t about being number one, but about coming together as one. Remember the words sung by Don Kawaʻahau “All the fighting that the king has done, he sees his kingdom now divided everybody trying to be number one. Every group got their own agenda, they all say that their way is better. Self-determination can be achieved if we all just come together.”

To you, the younger generation, the future guardians of Lahaina. Now is the moment to rise, to rebuild, to rekindle. Honor the rich tapestry of cultures that make our town so distinct. Ensure the continuation of our gatherings, our laughter, our shared stories. Let’s ensure Lahaina remains a sanctuary where, at day’s end, we can all find joy.  Get involved in your community.  And most importantly, talk to your kupuna and learn all that you can while you still can. 

For those beyond our shores, grasp our struggle. Understand our deep-seated love for our town and the heartache of potentially never witnessing its glory again. Our fight extends beyond mere bricks and mortar - we battle for our history, our culture, our identity.

Tag someone who needs this message to resonate within them. Let’s draw in those who can aid us. Together, let’s rally, let’s reconstruct, let’s remember. Lahaina’s heartbeat calls us.

“In every community, there is work to be done. In every nation, there are wounds to heal. In every heart, there is the power to do it.” Let’s harness that power and heal our beloved Lahaina together.

🔥ANNOUNCEMENT🔥 Lahaina, we need YOU. 🌊

Mark your calendars for the 24th 🗓️ Your voice matters, let’s make it heard! 📢

#CWRMmeeting #StandUp #SpeakOut #CommunityPower #TakeAction #LahainaStrong

E hoʻi ka nani o Lahaina - The glory of Lahaina will be restored!

🌊 ‘Ola i ka Wai’ - Water is Life. It’s a simple truth we’ve always known, and now it’s time to voice it. Our waters are in peril, and we need YOU to stand with us.

Join us on Tuesday, October 24th at the J. Walter Cameron Center Auditorium in Wailuku, 95 Mahalani St., at 9:00am. This isn’t just about us, it’s about our children, our grandchildren, and the generations yet unborn. We owe it to them to fight for a future where water flows freely, nourishing our land and our souls.

Your voice can make a difference. Let’s unite as one, testify, and demand a better future for our waters and our people. RSVP today - link in bio. Together, we can ensure that water remains life.

The battle for Lahaina's future is upon us, and it's a fight we cannot afford to lose. The echoes of our struggles are not just headlines - they're real stories of pain, resilience, and determination. This fight has been going on behind the scenes for decades.  Now it’s time for us to join the fight, and stand together!

Our waters, our lifeblood, are at stake. We cannot stand by while our children's future dries up. It's time to rally, to roar louder than ever, to demand what is rightfully ours.

This is not just about us. This is about every generation that comes after us. We have a duty to protect their future, to ensure they inherit a Lahaina that is vibrant and alive.

Join us on Tuesday, October 24th at the J. Walter Cameron Center Auditorium in Wailuku, 95 Mahalani St., at 9:00am. Stand shoulder to shoulder with your neighbors, your friends, your family. Raise your voice and testify for our right to water.

RSVP today - Link in bio. Your presence can tip the scales. Together, we can and will reclaim our waters.
PSA For A Crucial Meeting We Need You Apart of This Tuesday, October 24th at 9am at J. Walter Cameron Center Auditorium #lahainastrong

When we look at what was, we see what could be. We see solutions to modern problems.

In the mo’olelo of Lahaina, or Lele as it is known, we learn how green it was. How fertile it was with ‘ulu, kalo, niu, and other crops that were carefully cultivated over the span of hundreds if not thousands of years. 

We hear how it was cooler, how the palapalai ferns that once grew in groves glistened with dew. And if you know anything about palapalai you understand that it needs a lot of shade and water to thrive. 

We remember how the fertility extended all the way down through fishponds, to the shore, and stretched out into the surrounding sea.

It’s no wonder then that Lahaina was once the capital of the Hawaiian Kingdom. It was most likely the place on Maui that once had the highest concentration of people because of its ‘āina. ‘Āina is what happens when people, cultural practice, and place come together in ways that create abundance; An abundance that’s not possible without the proper care, connections, and collaborations with wai.

When plantations took over, they plowed through and burned the ‘ulu forests down. They diverted, banked, and hoarded water. The same forests that took thousands of years to grow and cultivate were gone in less than a few decades. The water that sustained life in the ‘āina of Lahaina was drained away.

Today, the business of exploitation and greed lives on in corporations that continue to prioritize profits over the planet and the local people as water diversion, banking, and hoarding continues to be a problem.

It’s a problem because the laws that are in place to ensure water’s proper flow and usage are not being followed or enforced. 

Today’s officials have an opportunity to be pono if they listen to the community, restore stream flow, and return the water to where it should be. Restoring Lahaina, restoring Lele, needs wai. Food, fair housing, regenerative industry, schools, security, protection, life all begins with water.

When future generations look back at today, what will they see?

E ho’i ka nani.
May the glory return.

Hālau Lahaina, malu i ka ‘ulu.
Lahaina is a great place of learning, peace, protection, and abundance.

🔥 The recent fires have not only left a trail of destruction but also highlighted a deep-rooted issue - our housing crisis. This crisis, which was present even before the flames, has now been amplified, leaving many in our community grappling with the harsh reality of being priced out of their own paradise.

The fires have sparked more than just devastation - they’ve ignited a call for change. Our community has long faced the harsh reality of skyrocketing housing costs, forcing many to abandon their homes in the land they love. And now, the fires have added to this struggle.

Our petition (link in bio) is an urgent call to action. It’s our united voice against this ongoing injustice. Your signature is more than just ink on paper - it’s a pledge to stand against the forces that threaten our community.

We cannot sit idly by while our neighbors lose their homes and livelihoods. It’s time to rise from the ashes and demand change. By signing our petition, you’re joining a community that refuses to be silenced. Together, we can ensure that Hawaii remains a paradise for all, not just the privileged few.

Colonization. Plantations. Sugar. Water. Corporations. Government. Greedy developers. Extractive and unfettered tourism. Why did Maui burn? If you haven’t yet read @newyorkermag’s comprehensive article on Lahaina and the fires, here are some excerpts:

“Peter Martin, West Maui Land’s co-founder and C.E.O., told me that protecting water for Native Hawaiian cultural practices was “a crock of shit,” and that invasive grasses and “this stupid climate-change thing” had “nothing to do with the fire.” ... Maui’s lands, he added, “weren’t being used as God intended.”

“Lahaina, which means “cruel sun,” sits on the leeward side of Maui, below the western mountains, Mauna Kahālāwai, which roughly translates to “house of water.” The highest peak is one of the wettest places in the world, historically receiving about three hundred and sixty-six inches of rain per year.”

“During the American Civil War, the agricultural economy that sustained Southern farmers collapsed, and Hawaii became a primary source of sugar ... One ton of sugar requires a million gallons of water. To meet that demand, private companies producing sugar rerouted the flow from Maui’s watersheds. European ranchers introduced non-native, drought-resistant African grasses ... In less than five decades, the island’s landscape and ecology were dramatically altered.”

“Plantation owners abandoned vast swaths of farmland, allowing the non-native grasses to proliferate. Instead of restoring the steep mountain streams, they left their diversions in place—in some cases, dumping water into dry gulches, or directly into the ocean—or used them to develop beachfront resorts, with lush gardens, swimming pools, and golf courses.”

“By 1996, as Carol Wilcox writes in her chronicle “Sugar Water,” “competition for water had met the limits of the resource in Lahaina.” That same year, the newly formed West Maui Land Company started buying abandoned plantations (and their valuable irrigation systems) and creating new subdivisions.”

Much more to unpack and learn from beyond these excerpts. Read the article and share it with others. Link at kanaeokana.net/links [link in bio].

#lahainastrong #lahaina #maui #mauistrong

“For the last hundred and fifty years, Hawaii’s gone in the wrong direction. This situation we’re in right now? It brought that to light.” — Archie Kalepa

Learn more about the issue, click the link in our bio!

#mauinokaoi #lahainastrong #mauistrong #mauihawaii

This Friday, we’re taking a stand - Fishing for Lahaina at Kaanapali Beach! 🎣 Our community has been ignored for too long. Let’s see them ignore us as we fish in front of the very hotels our people are being displaced from. 💪

We DEMAND action NOW! Join us until the Mayor/Gov step up and use their emergency powers to house our residents. 🏠 Most of these Short-term rentals were OUR homes before tourism took over.😡

We’ll stay out here until the village is fed. We are more than just a tourist destination. We are a community. We are Lahaina Strong. ✊ See you at Kaʻanapali Beach! 📍#FishingForLahaina #OccupyKB #TakeAStand #CommunityFirst

Join us on November 10th at Kā'anapali Beach! The Lahaina Strong Hui calls on our community to exercise our rights, drawing attention to the sheltering crisis in Lahaina. We demand urgent action from Mayor Bissen and Governor Green to convert short-term rentals into long-term housing. Let's stand together and hold space for as long as it takes. Details below.
- Follow Code of Conduct at ALL TIMES (swipe for code of conduct)
- Check in at Lahaina Strong tent when you arrive
- Come Self Sustainable & bring what you will need
- Pack it in / Pack it out
- Check the Needs List before coming and try to bring something to donate to support
#LahainaStrong #CommUNITY
#FishingForLahaina #FishingForHousing
#EmpowerThePeople

We Invite You To Join Us This Friday And However Many Days We Have To Occupy Ka’anapali Beach & To Sign The Petition To Push For Long-term Term Housing For Our Displaced Families Here In Lahaina. Mahalos @paele_kulani For Talking Story With Me #lahainastrong

text_entities.entity: beach & to sign the petition to push for longterm term housing for our displaced families

social_posts.post_text:
Day 1 of #OccupyKaanapaliBeach is in the books! 🏖️ Rows of tents, flags flying high, and a sea of red ‘Lahaina Strong’ shirts swept through the hotels and Whalers Village. It was nothing short of amazing. ✨

And believe it or not, all of this happened in less than 24 hours! That’s the power of our community. 💪

We’ve got our informational tent up, keiki crafts happening, and a medic tent ready. But this movement is a process and we’re still growing. We’re building out our security team, organizing donated goods, and securing necessary supplies and storage. 

As this movement grows, so does the responsibility of those involved. If you’re wearing a Lahaina Strong shirt, you’re representing us. You’re showing that you stand with the community and are committed to acting in a manner that is pono. 🌺

Here’s the truth: people are watching us, waiting for us to fail. They want to capitalize on any moment of weakness and shut us down before we get our demands met. But we won’t let that happen. We HAVE TO rise above and be pono, always. Don’t be the person who ruins it for the community we hold so dearly. Let’s continue to build, grow, and fight for our home. Lahaina Strong forever. 🔥

Now, we’re calling on YOU. Whether you’re from Lahaina or beyond, we need you. Come join us, take up space, and let your voice be heard. Together, we can bring about positive, lasting change. This is more than just a movement, it’s a revolution. Be a part of it. Stand with us at Kaanapali Beach. #LahainaStrong #CommunityFirst #TakeAStand #JoinTheRevolution

BREAKING: Less than one week after 28 grassroots groups launched our Fish-in for Housing with the demand to @countyofmaui Mayor Bissen to ensure dignified interim housing for our people by converting short-term rentals to long-term rentals, he announced that they are pursuing pathways to do just that—including considering using his executive authority if the industry does not voluntarily comply. These words spoken at @hawaiiancouncil Native Hawaiian Convention are a major victory that would not have been possible without our collective movement, but we need more than words, we need action.

We need the Mayor to clearly communicate his plan for housing security to all our people before the November 30th deadline. We will keep up the pressure until a real pathway is presented for every family to have the peace of mind they need. Call the Mayor’s office at (808) 270-7855 and ask him to use his authority to expand long-term rentals and communicate the plan for housing security with the public. Join us on Sunday at Whalers Village beach from 9-1 for an ‘Ohana Friendly Ocean Day with Kahākūkahi to keep up the momentum.

“Although the physical fires are no longer burning, the fire amongst our people still burn bright.” 
 
Watch the full speech of Lahaina’s own Paele Kiakona on our YouTube channel. Find more keynote speeches and panel discussions from the 22nd Annual Native Hawaiian Convention there. 
 
“Ke kukui pio ʻole i ka makani o Kauaʻula. The ever burning torch that not even the fierce winds of Kauaʻula can extinguish. And I firmly believe that we are product of our environment.”
 
#hawaiiancouncil #NativeHawaiianConvention #kakoomaui
null

Day 9 at #OccupyKaanapaliBeach, and our resolve is unshakeable! 🌴 Our peaceful, family-friendly occupation has made waves, with the Mayor announcing they’re working on transforming short-term rentals into long-term housing. Yet, as many in our community still face evictions and hotel switches at the end of the month, our fight continues. 🌺

As we approach LāKūʻokoʻa (Hawaiian Independence Day), we’re extending an invitation far beyond Lahaina. We’re calling on you, wherever you are, to join us in this pivotal moment. Bring your flags and let’s blanket one of the world’s most beautiful beaches with symbols of unity and resistance. 🏳️🚩

Kamehameha III (Kauikeaouli) said our Hawaiian flag is a flag that represents aloha, lōkahi (harmony), and holomua (progress). 

It is important to see our flag proudly displayed because that is what we all need to get through this time. 

To our brothers and sisters in the hotels, grappling with eviction and stress, hear this: You don’t have to stand - we will stand for you. We see you. We are here for you. And we will fight for you. 🤝

This is more than a protest. It’s a beacon of hope. It’s a chance for you to make a difference, to lend your voice to those who can’t raise theirs right now. Experience the beauty of Kaanapali Beach not just as a paradise, but as a battleground for justice.

So, pack your tents and come down. Lend your presence to our cause. Feel the power of community and the spirit of resistance. This is #LahainaStrong. Together, we rise. 🌅 #LāKūʻokoʻa #OccupyKaanapaliBeach

Mahalo nunui CNHA @hawaiiancouncil for the opportunity to repurpose flags put up at the conference this past week in Maui in honor of each person who perished in the fire.

Day 11 at #OccupyKaanapaliBeach and our resolve is stronger than ever! 🌴 We’ve been connecting with visitors from around the world, revealing the reality of our struggle for dignified housing for our fire victims. 💔

Hotel executives may frame this as a battle between tourists and residents, but the truth is different. The visitors we’ve spoken to stand united with us! They see our fight, they hear our stories, and they advocate for us. Their advocacy speaks volumes - because if the voices that fuel the economy speak for us, they cannot be ignored. 💬🌍 

Dear Mayor, @countyofmaui your city’s guests are standing with us, advocating for us. They see the urgency of our plight, the need for stable homes for those affected by the fires. Will you listen to them? Will you listen to us? 🙏

This is more than a beach occupation. It’s a platform for education, a call to action, a plea for humanity. It’s one of the world’s most beautiful beaches turned into a stage for social justice.

The world is watching, Mayor. The world is waiting. And so are we. 🌅 #OccupyKaanapaliBeach #TouristsForLahaina #LahainaStrong

Despite giant swell, Lahaina Strong organizers remain relentless while ‘fishing for housing’.

“I’m willing to give my life for my place. I love this place more than anything. So, I know that if I’m still breathing, we’re still winning. So, keep your hopes high,” Paele Kiakona said.

Story on @HawaiiNewsNow. @chelseadavishnn 

#HawaiiNewsNow #HawaiiNews #lahaina #lahainastrong #mauistrong #fishingforhousing #housingcrisis #maui #haeaii #trending

When we unite as a community, our collective strength transforms into a powerful force against all odds. Leaders who choose to stand with us will feel this power and support.

Even in the heat of our struggle, our spirit and determination remain unbroken. Our voices continue to echo through every discussion, every meeting - we are a constant presence, tirelessly advocating for our cause.

We fight not just for ourselves, but for the soul of our entire pae ʻāina. Our commitment runs deep, as deep as our love for this place we call home.

Remember, every breath we take is a victory. Every day we continue to fight is a triumph. We’re here, standing together, fighting for each other, for Lahaina, for Hawaiʻi.

Stay inspired, stay strong, and keep fighting. Together, we can achieve anything. #StandWithLahaina #LahainaStrong #KeepFighting

To our brothers and sisters still stuck in the hotels, grappling with the uncertainty of eviction and the weight of stress, let these words resonate with you: You don’t have to stand - we will stand for you.

We see you, we feel your struggle. We too have walked through the fire, felt the heat, seen our world change overnight. But like a sunrise over Lahaina, we found hope and new beginnings amidst the ashes. And now, we extend our hands, firmly rooted in the strength we’ve found, ready to be your rock, your fortress.

This is more than just a protest. It’s a beacon of hope, a symbol of resilience, a testament to our collective strength. So, as the waves crash on the shores of Kaanapali Beach, let them not just be a reminder of the paradise we live in, but also of the battleground we’re prepared to defend.

Remember, you’re not alone in this battle. Rest, recover. We will stand for you, fight for you. This is our pledge, our duty, our honor. Today, tomorrow, always, we stand as one. #LahainaStrong #CommunityUnity #WeStandTogether 🌅🔥💪

“The young are stepping to the front, and sometimes we got to recognize as the older guys and .. step back but help carry them along, because when we pau, they the ones going be there.” - Kekai Keahi, Lahaina community leader.

Eō! Mahalo @hawaiiancouncil for sharing.

It’s been about a month since the full reopening of West Maui following the Aug. 8 wildfire that killed nearly 100 people and caused billions of dollars in damage. While many tourists are eager to do their part to help reboot the local economy, Lahaina families say they aren’t emotionally ready. VC @newsnationnow 

#Hawaii #mauistrong #lahaina #lahainastrong #fishingforhousing #housingcrisis #maui

Join us for a historic event with Lāhainā Strong on December 20th to support Lāhainā fire victims and advocate for dignified housing. ILWU and Local 5 unite in this remarkable collaboration for the first time in history, symbolizing our community's strength and solidarity.

Meet us at 3 PM on the beach by the fishing for housing camp in front of Leilani’s wearing red. Bring empowering signs as we march from Kā’anapali Parkway to the highway, embodying Kapu Aloha spirit in a respectful, family-friendly demonstration.

This march is more than an event; it's a powerful statement for housing rights. Stand with us, voice your support, and be part of a movement that champions our community's resilience and unity. Together, we are a force for change.

#lahainastrong #fishingforhousing #fishingfordignifiedhousing #makinghistory #unityinaloha

Help Maui Rise & Lāhainā Strong are coming together this holiday season to help raise donations for the displaced ‘ohana of Lāhainā and Kula. 
 
A week ago, we put out a call to our Hawai’i community to donate ornaments that were designed with Maui in mind. To say that they showed up would be an understatement. Within 5 days we had about 500 ornaments with over a hundred more on the way. Our goal is to have 1,500, one ornament for every family on the @helpmauirise list. 
 
Each ornament will be hung on the @officiallahainastrong tree at the Fishing for Housing occupation at Whaler’s Village. Ornaments can be purchased for a minimum donation of $100. Simply come down, scan the QR code and help a family in need. Please help us to kāko’o and bring some light to these families in a time where they need it most.
 
We can’t tag all of you but we wanted to give a special thanks to the many contributors who made this possible: 

@junglegrrly @kennananananana  @aja.toscano @jor_ruidas  @mauimasa  @ourspacehawaii @erkaerka @punkyaloha @misscourtneyyy_ @dyomogida @manaiakalanimedia @kanonodreamportal @_maimaimade_ @adamjk @nailsbyai___ @itsopal.wav @kaimahie_ @shewoodgo @vivistop_honolulu @seiya.later @krizhnab @amandaxbrittany @chanelgariando @okanojoyce @zebu.ceramica @dhennelly @luis_castrom33 @chy.animal @maidensofthepacific @jamielynndee @theverycoolstudio @hi_lauriemiyoko @hidarlingshop @uluaina @koakards @alohaleelo @kailatoetuu @tamikoclairestoneware @tylerdoo @malie_designs @jesnajdek @shopcasaclara @cienaalagao @harumitoscano @jerilynch ❣️

Lahaina,This is just what we do! We show up! We take care of each other! 

Join us for a historic event with Lähaina Strong on December 20th to support Lahaina fire victims and advocate for dignified housing. ILWU and Local 5 unite in this remarkable collaboration for the first time in history, symbolizing our community’s strength and solidarity.
Meet us at 3 PM on the beach by the fishing for housing camp in front of Leilani’s wearing red.
Bring empowering signs as we march from Ka’anapali Parkway to the highway, embodying Kapu Aloha spirit in a respectful, family-friendly demonstration.
This march is more than an event; it’s a powerful statement for housing rights. Stand with us, voice your support, and be part of a movement that champions our community’s resilience and unity.
Together, we are a force for change.
#lahainastrong #fishingforhousing #fishingfordignifiedhousing #makinghistory

Lahaina Strong x @ilwulocal142hawaii x @uniteherehawaii RALLY♥️

#lahainastrong #peopleoverprofit #dignifiedhousing #wedidthat

WOW…. We did that Lahaina♥️ 

Mahalo to the community for coming out today, for ILWU and Local 5 for standing in solidarity with Lahaina and amplifying the voices of our people and most importantly, a huge mahalo to everyone who helped us @officiallahainastrong organize this historic event. That was AMAZING!!!!!🙌🏽

I also want to add, this is the first time since the 40’s that the two unions, ILWU and Local 5 came together to work as one and unified, and to have them support us is just incredible. Such a high🙏🏽

And these guys in the pictures are straight HAMMAHS!!! Definitely couldn’t pull this off without them (missing some from the photo). 

We love you Lahaina♥️ We’re making huge strides in the right direction. Keep applying pressure!💨

#lahaina #lahainastrong #fishingforhousing

Fed up with the lack of long-term housing, Maui wildfire survivors took the the streets Wednesday and rallied alongside community members.

Hundreds gathered at the opposite end of the Kaanapali, in front of the Westin, and marched up to Kaanapali Parkway where they waved signs.

The march was led by community advocacy group “Lahaina Strong,” hotel workers with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, and Unite Here Local 5.

They’re calling this rally for dignified housing “Maui Families First.”

Krizhna Bayudan, a member of the Maui Tenants and Workers Association, told Hawaii New Now it’s been months since she was able to find a place to call home.

“My family amongst others displaced have had to move around five times, have had to live in suitcases and not know when or where the next move will be,” she said. “It’s been over 4 months and we still don’t have a place where we can call home.”

ILWU Local 142 President Chris West said everyone is at their tipping point.

“I think everybody’s at the point now where somebody come up with the answer. Somebody make a move, somebody take that bold, that bold statement or decision — like the governor recently made — and take the lead in this,” he said during the rally.

Members of Lahaina Strong have been camping in front of the resorts in Kaanapali since Nov. 10. They have their fishing poles and say they are fishing for housing.

They also say they will be out there for however long it takes for government leaders to provide them with appropriate housing solutions for residents who were displaced by the August fires. #repost @chelseadavishnn @hawaiinewsnow 

#lahaina #maui #kaanapali #kaanapalibeach #mauistrong #lahainastrong #fishingforhousing #housingcrisis #housingcrisis #hawaii #ilwulocal13
Day 46
It’s a long video but important to hear. Update on Olowalu dump site. Please share so our people can see.

🔥 Ignite the flame of change! Urgent Call to Action: Rally for Affordable Housing and Unleash the Power! 🔨🏡

Time is dwindling to shape a better future for our communities. Unite with us in urging Governor Green to transform short-term rentals into lasting, dignified homes for our people. Extend the eviction and rent increase moratorium beyond January 5th, 2024.

Every family deserves a secure and affordable sanctuary. It’s time to rise up and mend the housing crisis fueled by short-term rentals. 💪🏠 The evidence speaks volumes – a complete ban on short-term rentals could be Hawaiʻiʻs housing crisis antidote.

Dial Governor Green at 808-586-0034 and amplify your message through governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/contact-the-governor/. Let your voice resonate, championing the call to drop the hammer on this issue. Together, we forge a radiant future for all. 🗣️

#LahainaStrong
#AffordableHousingMatters #ExtendTheMoratorium #DropTheHammer #HousingCrisisSolution #TogetherWeCanMakeAChange

text_entities.entity: call to action rally for affordable

social_posts.post_text:
Day 56: The sun sets on another day of our unwavering commitment to the #FishingForHousing campaign at Kaanapali Beach. Each sunset is a testament to our resilience, a symbol of our steadfast dedication to our cause. Lahaina Strong, we’ve been at the helm of this movement, tirelessly advocating for dignified housing for our cherished community.

We’ve come a long way, growing stronger each day. The journey has been filled with countless moments of unity and determination. Like this unity march on day 41 that saw over 1,000 voices resonate with ours.  The strategic and historic alliances forged with two of Hawaii’s largest unions, made up of our working class community, marching together, with Lahaina Strong following behind and pushing them forward.

To the Lahaina community, your indomitable spirit fuels this movement. Every conversation, every shared story, every moment of solidarity adds to the momentum. Your unwavering support has been the heart of this campaign.

Let’s take a moment to reflect on how far we’ve come. We’ve educated, campaigned, strategized, and above all, stood together in the face of adversity. We’re not just making strides, we’re making history.

As we continue this journey, remember this - Lahaina Strong isn’t just a name, it’s a testament to who we are. We lead, we persevere, and we triumph. Here’s to the victories behind us and those on the horizon. We press on, for the love of Lahaina. #LahainaStrong #DignifiedHousingNow

Mahalo to @mat5o and @chris_mckeown_photography for providing footage for this video.

Press conferences and promises aside, we remain steadfast in our mission to see our people in dignified long term housing. The occupation hasn’t been easy, we fight off storms, swells, tweakers and infection, and we were hoping we’d be wrapping up soon based on recent updates, but after the disappointment, we’ve adapted, grown stronger, and we’re ready to double down on our efforts.

When tourism opened up, we held back the tide of radical action to maintain peace, despite the tourism storm that caught us off guard. Clearly, we weren’t the only ones unprepared; the government seems to be in the same boat.

But this isn’t a defeat. Our demand for a moratorium is still very much alive. 

Transparency has been scarce, and it’s testing our patience. It’s time for Lahaina’s voice to be heard in the decisions that affect us. 

By partnering with @helpmauirise on our Christmas Ornament “adopt a family” project, We’ve raised over $60K from tourists directly benefiting families via their Venmo and GoFundMe, and we’ve shown we are a force to be reckoned with.

As we gear up for the Onipaʻa March on Oʻahu and the upcoming legislative session, remember this: the conversation is about Lahaina. We are Lahaina Strong, and we won’t stop until we achieve dignified housing for all. Stay tuned, the fight continues. #LahainaStrong #DignifiedHousingNow #LahainaStrongNews

As Lahaina Strong, the heart of our community always guides our actions. As the Lele Aloha Unity March on Jan 20th approaches, we’ve listened to our community’s concerns and sentiments. Many of us agree - it doesn’t feel pono for us to participate in an event that doesn’t resonate with our spirit. 

Lahaina Strong stands for transparency and being a voice for the community.  When we move, we move with purpose. 
Our fight continues - immediate, long-term, dignified housing for our people. There can be no unity without community, and our community still cries out for housing. No housing, no peace. 

For those that wish to attend know that we love and support you and wish we could attend as it will probably be beautiful. 

However, we cannot align ourselves with an event that has significant government involvement when many of our community’s struggles stem from both governmental inaction and making decisions that further hurt us. We cannot march alongside them under the national media spotlight, potentially enabling a narrative that suggests we stand in unity with those we feel have  ignored us, overlooked our needs and have not followed through on their promises to help us. 

We have spoken with thousands of tourists during this occupation. Our visitors often perceive that all is well in Lahaina. They believe we are being taken care of and are happy. This is not our truth. We cannot allow this perception to perpetuate unchallenged. We must voice our reality.

While we won’t participate in the march, we’re hosting an event at the beach that day for our community members who wish to stand with their people and enjoy a nice Ohana day at the beach. 
#LahainaStrong #NoHousingNoPeace”

Mauinui
Lāhainā Strong Organizer 
President of Save Honolua Coalition
E Ola Ka ‘Ōlelo Hawaii
